ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: As a language class, Legal Spanish was a mix of lecture and discussion, although there was pretty limited discussion in this course.

having slides for class content was easier to follow (especially for someone who is not confident in their Spanish-listening abilities); liked having the asynchronous days to take the pressure off/dive into the material without the pressure of class
Virtual seminar with some recorded lectures

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the judicial system in the US and in Latin American countries. Most of the things we learned, I had never learned in English so it was interesting to learn completely new material in a different language for the first time. Through the course, I think my writing abilities in Spanish improved a great deal.

In this class, I improved my Spanish language skills, particularly my writing skills. This was the first time that I've written a 10 page paper in Spanish, so it was a new experience, but I was successfully able to navigate the writing process, which marks significant growth in my Spanish skills.
I learned a lot more about legal systems in both the US and outside. It was interesting to be exposed to different texts and media, and to be able to discuss them in a different language.

I didn't learn all that much to be honest, which was a bit disappointing. I mostly wanted to practice speaking, but there was not much participation in our classes and because of that every time I spoke I felt like there was more pressure to speak correctly, which made me nervous about participating. I did learn a lot of random stuff about legal theory and the Spanish legal system, which I guess could be useful for law school.
listening and speaking skills improved; content was interesting, but perhaps too broad
I practiced more Spanish

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: weakness- way too much busywork

I think this course took advantage of the virtual model very well. We had asynchronous class on certain days, which was really well-received. At times, it felt a bit more like a lecture than a seminar, which made it a bit difficult to participate. The class met a 9am on Tues/Thurs, but we regularly had assignments due at 9am on Fridays, Sundays, and Mondays. It was a bit difficult to manage these assignments with such strange times.

The biggest strength of this course was the student presentations, which were an excellent way to learn from and with my classmates. With that said, many of the assignments in this course seemed unrelated to the course material, so sometimes it was difficult to engage with or prepare for classes. This course could be improved by more visual aids and greater synergy between the homework and in class work.

The class would have benefitted from having more activities in class asides from just free discussion. Otherwise, homework assignments were helpful with writing better, especially because Professor Verastegui gave detailed and clear feedback to help without writing.
Too much work, but the in-class collaboration was great. Professor Verstegui was incredible

There should have been much more rapid fire ask and respond participation in the class to help everyone participate more and practice our Spanish. I wanted to talk but didn't really feel comfortable because the class was about 90% lecture from the professor.

The only suggestions I have for improving the course would be to allow students to engage more in discussions and make the lectures more interactive. All of the classes were probably 90% lecture and 10% of actual discussion. While I certainly feel like I improved my reading and writing skills, this class did not help very much in improving my conversational skills.

strengths: interesting content; professor invested in your learning 

weaknesses: class discussion is sometimes overwhelming so I would have liked to have participated in more breakout rooms for discussions; class content seemed a bit unfocused and broad
I think there could have been more opportunity for students to practice their verbal skills.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the asynchronous parts were very effective.

I think that the student presentations were helpful and easy to engage with, but I had more trouble with the discussion portion of the class. I think that it could be improved by having more interactive elements as well as providing more visual aids/ways for student to read new words, instead of just hearing them.
This was a pretty normal language class I think. Our professor was new to teaching, so I think there was a bit of a learning curve there which was a challenge at the beginning of the semester.
I wish there had been more breakout rooms
The occasional recorded class worked really well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No (not if its online)- there was way too much unnecessary busywork. The professor also just spoke for 50 minutes straight (perhaps this would be a better course to take during non-pandemic times)

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Especially for those interested in politics and the judicial system, it gives a really interesting and comprehensive overview of current events and their legal implications.

I think I would recommend this course in non-COVID times, but may not recommend it via Zoom. It was sometimes difficult to learn this material via Zoom, but I still feel that I grew as a Spanish speaker and writer.
Yes but this is not a "gut," you might be graded generously but there is constant work

If you need an L5 Spanish course, this one is probably a good bet considering that it's not too hard to get a good grade and there isn't all that much work. On the other hand, it was pretty tedious and not very enjoyable.
Id recommend taking this class as an interesting L5 course, but be prepared to write a ~lot~ for homework!
I would if they need the FL credit.
